captions.text: A layout as large as Wunderland
needs, besides everyday cleaning,
some special maintenance measures.
Therefore, many Wunderlanders gather
for a nightshift in order to clean tracks and streets.
But, what exactly is there to do?
On the agenda for today:
Twice a year we have to clean the tracks.
The trains generate incredible amounts of dirt,
and also lose some oil while driving.
With the wheels the trains grind in the dust
which our guests bring into our layout.
The result: A grimy film on the tracks.
If you wipe with a finger over it,
you'll get a black mark on your skin.
That's why the tracks get cleaned twice a year
with an abrasive block like this one,
which can be purchased,
almost like an eraser.
In the meantime  at the Airport:
Our model maker are making preparations.
They remove dirt from the streets
and the airfield, meticulously.
They have to pay attention while moving across the layout,
because otherwise, the delicate contacts for the traffic
might malfuction easily.
Actually, the car traffic is the reason for this endeavor.
We noticed that our streets are worn
to a degree where the cars
stop moving frequently by now.
That means, we have to apply new coating.
Before we apply a new finish, we have to
sand back the old laquer.
After we're done with sanding,
there's quite some amount of sanding dust.
We have to remove it before laquering.
It's best done by wiping it roughly with a
wet sponge, wiping it dry, and then applying the new finish.
We have to be careful not to miss even a millimeter
when cleaning the tracks.
Sometimes our staff even has to
balance on the tracks.
Especially in the staging yards
it's not easy to work with the abrasive block.
After we rubbed everything off,
we have to arm ourselves with dust busters,
in order to vacuum everything well, especially the switches,
because here the crumbs gather,
and the switches won't turn properly.
Here we go for another round.
Thanks to long vacuum hoses more relaxed than while rubbing.
Knuffingen gets wet.
Christian distributes a special laquer to the other staff.
They are applying the liquid on the cleaned streets
with foam rollers.
There's texture paste in the laquer.
Now we have to apply it carefully with the roller.
We have to be careful with the amount we use.
It may neither be too much nor too little.
It's always a balancing act working with the foam roller.
But we are experienced enough to know, roughly.
Tomorrow will tell, because then,
the pilot will let us know
whether it was good or not.
If not,  all the work was virtually in vain.
But...I'm positive!
In the staging yards the remaining tracks are being vacuumed.
In some places acrobatic skills and dexterity are called for.
Very tricky when cleaning visible areas of the layout,
and every railway hobbyist knows it: Catenaries!
The nuzzle needs to go underneath to vacuum the tracks,
and every time it snags.
For whoever sets up the catenaries
it's always a horror to see it when he comes in
the morning after the cleaning.
We do this every six month.  In fact, we have to,
because otherwise, the layout would look beneath contempt.
To prevent that from happening, our busy Wunderlanders
will now spend a few nights cleaning tracks and switches,
and to maintain the Airport layout.
But even when things get tight, there's always an allowance for fun!

title: MiWuLa TV Report - Wunderland in Lack und Glanz
